content: The "Thomas Alva Edison Commemorative Coin Act" recognizes Thomas A. Edison's contributions as an inventor. Edison was born in 1847 and created over 1,300 inventions, including the light bulb and phonograph. In 1928, he received the Congressional gold medal for his revolutionary inventions. 2024 will mark the 125th anniversary of the light bulb invention. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 500,000 $1 coins in honor of the 125th anniversary of Thomas A. Edison's light bulb invention. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary can obtain silver from various sources for minting the coins. The design of the coins minted under this Act will be emblematic of Thomas A. Edison's inventions, with inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The obverse of each coin will bear the likeness of Thomas A. Edison. The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities starting on January 1, 2004, with minting authority ending on December 31, 2004. All sales of coins minted under this Act include a $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharges received will be distributed to various organizations for specific purposes, such as the Museum of Arts and History in Port Huron, Michigan, and the Edison Birthplace Association in Milan, Ohio. Up to 1/8 of the surcharges will go to the National Park Service. Up to 1/8 of the surcharges from coin sales will be allocated to different organizations for specific purposes related to Thomas A. Edison, including the National Park Service for protecting historic documents, the Edison Plaza Museum for educational programs, the Edison Winter Home and Museum for preservation, and the Edison Institute for maintaining displays and educational programs. The Edison memorial tower in New Jersey and the Hall of electrical history in New York receive funding for preservation, restoration, and educational programs related to Thomas A. Edison. Organizations receiving payments are subject to audit requirements.
